subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit licensing issues
msgSnippet: ... I am not a lawyer. However, all work in Java inherits from Sun s basic Java classes. Therefore, by your reasoning, any software written in Java is a
messageBody:
On Tue, 24 Jun 2003, spam_if_you_want_to wrote:

> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Jim Dixon <jdd@d...> wrote:
>
> > After a quick review of the JUnit license, I would say that you can
> > include the code but must identify it as JUnit code and state that that
> > part of the software is released under the JUnit license, which you
> > should supply a copy of.
>
> I'm not including any JUnit code. I am inheriting from JUnit classes.
> Under copyright law, this makes my program a 'dervived work' of
> JUnit, even though I have not copied any JUnit code.

I am not a lawyer.

However, all work in Java inherits from Sun's basic Java classes.
Therefore, by your reasoning, any software written in Java is a
derived work. I doubt very much that any court would accept this
reasoning.

My advice remains the same: acknowledge the JUnit license, tell
people where to get the code or include it, and then forget the
matter: you have done what the license requires you to do.

--
Jim Dixon jdd@... tel +44 117 982 0786 mobile +44 797 373 7881
